Accurate detection of blade damages, particularly cracks, is crucial for sustained operations and cost savings. Traditionally, damage inspection has been a manual process, making it subjective, error-prone, and time-consuming. To address this, we introduce a deep learning-based approach to bring objectivity, scalability, and repeatability to our damage inspection process, reducing the likelihood of missing cracks. We train a deep learning model on a large dataset of blade damages collected through drone-based inspections to accurately detect cracks. Our model, already in production, has processed over a million damages with a recall of 0.96. We also focus on model interpretability using class activation maps to gain insights into the model's workings. The model performs as well as human experts and even outperforms them in certain challenging cases.

The increasing global energy demand, projected to rise by 4.6% in 2021, highlights the need for renewable energy sources. Wind energy is expected to be a prominent source by 2050, but its adoption is hindered by high operational and maintenance (O&M) costs, which account for 20-24% of the total Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) of current wind systems. Blade failures are a significant contributor to these costs, as turbines operate in harsh conditions and are made of complex, expensive materials. Damages on wind turbine blades, especially cracks, can indicate severe internal structural damage and lead to costly repairs if left unchecked.

There are various types of cracks, including longitudinal, transverse, diagonal, and buckling, each with distinct visual appearances. Additionally, other damage types, such as chips, flaking, and scratches, can resemble cracks but are less severe. The challenge lies in correctly identifying all crack sub-types and distinguishing them from similar-looking damages. This process is typically manual, labor-intensive, and prone to errors.

Deep learning can improve upon human analysts and classical image processing methods by identifying discriminative features to distinguish cracks from similar-looking damages. We focus on developing an accurate, fast, and reliable deep learning-based method to identify cracks on wind turbine blades. Our goal is to integrate deep learning into our Quality Check (QC) process to reduce the likelihood of missing cracks.

Drone-based inspections have shown promise in reducing turbine downtimes and human risk. We perform drone-based inspections for wind farms, capturing images in various orientations, lighting, and weather conditions. From this, we curate a dataset of 71k images and train a ResNet-50 model with specific training strategies. We test the model on real-world data and deploy it in production, with human analysts reviewing any disagreements between the model and their assessments.

Related work in this domain has used classical methods to detect cracks but struggled to distinguish them from similar-looking damages. Deep learning has been applied to surface damage detection in various materials, but limited work has been done on this specific problem. Existing works have used convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to classify blade images as damaged or not, but suffered from limited image datasets and high false-positive rates.
